title: Mums warned not to try cot Instagram trend - as it could lead to A&E visit
text:

If you're looking for a little decor inspiration for your baby's nursery, you might take a look on Instagram.

And while you're scrolling through posts, you'll probably notice one particular item crop up in numerous photos.

A trend has emerged that sees parents draping canopies over their child's cot.

And while the finishing touch certainly makes the room look very pretty, it turns out it can actually prove very dangerous for your little one.

So dangerous in fact, that parents are being warned against putting one up - and the same goes for fairy lights.

After conducting research into the most dangerous Instagram nursery trends, Australian consumer outlet Choice has urged new mums and dads not to put style before safety when decorating.

They revealed how hundreds of children under the age of five are injured every year by nursery furniture and compiled a list of some of the most dangerous items, including fabric canopies, fairy lights, unsecured furniture and even soft toys.

Paediatrician Dr Ruth Barker further explained the hidden dangers.

She said: "It's important to create a space that is safe not only for their current abilities, but for the abilities they will develop over time.

"Parents need to anticipate and stay one jump ahead, because you don't want the first time they do something to be their last."

She then added a stark warning to parents about hanging pieces of fabric near a cot, sharing a haunting real life story.

"I've treated a baby who used a mosquito net to pull up to stand, and ended up wrapping it around her neck," she confessed.

"Luckily, her mother came into the room and found her dangling from the net before it was too late."

Dr Barker went on to say how fairy lights also pose a risk of strangulation, as well as electrocution if they plug in.

If they are battery powered, the batteries can also prove very dangerous to a child if they are easily released.

And in case you hadn't realised, even pillows are a threat to your little one.

"Even when lying flat, babies' heads naturally tip forward due to the shape of their skull," she explained.

"If you put a pillow under their head, it can exaggerate the angle, tipping their chin onto their chest, which can cause a slow suffocation known as positional asphyxiation."

So there you have it folks, always make sure to really think about what you're putting in your baby's room before you get carried away with the decorating.
description: A doctor has revealed just how dangerous it can be if a parent adds a popular item to their baby's cot
